question_text: What physical mechanisms cause the negative feedback loop that leads to flame extinction in concurrent flame spread over thermally-thick materials under low-speed convection conditions?
standard_answer: The negative feedback extinction mechanism in concurrent flame spread over thermally-thick materials arises from the interplay between flame spread rate, thermal penetration depth, and heat loss mechanisms. As the flame spread rate (V_f) decreases in low-speed convection, the solid residence time (t_s,res = L_pr/V_f) increases proportionally. This longer residence time allows for greater thermal penetration into the solid, as τ_h = √(α_s t_s,res). The increased thermal penetration depth reduces the temperature gradient at the pyrolysis front, which in turn decreases the conductive heat flux driving the flame spread. Simultaneously, the larger preheating zone length (L_pr) enhances surface re-radiation losses, as radiative heat flux scales with the exposed surface area. The radiation number R_rad,s = (σε_s(T_p^4 - T_∞^4))/(λ_g(T_f - T_p)/L_y) quantifies this effect, showing that radiative losses become more significant with larger L_y (characteristic length). This creates a self-reinforcing cycle: reduced V_f → increased t_s,res → increased τ_h → reduced temperature gradient → further reduced V_f. The paper explains that 'a slight decrease in the FSR will enlarge t_s,res as well as L_sx. Consequently, the larger L_sx in turn reduces the temperature gradient at the flame front while increases the surface re-radiation, leading to a further reduction in the FSR.' This negative feedback eventually drives the system to extinction when the heat losses exceed the energy available to sustain pyrolysis and flame propagation.
